topic_set_details.materiality_evidence: The teaching concerns an administrative act that was withdrawn (with retroactive effect) and addresses consequences of that withdrawal for the admissibility of a suspension request.
The holding interprets procedural admissibility conditions (être ou risquer d'être lésé) for a suspension under articles 14–15, i.e., procedural rules governing suspension requests.
The court applies standards for judicial control of interim relief (suspension de l'exécution) and decides admissibility when the contested act no longer causes prejudice.

retrieval_info.description: Use set intersection for retrieval: match sources where topic_set ∩ query_topics ≠ ∅ AND issue_type_set ∩ query_issue_types ≠ ∅
retrieval_info.retrieval_queries: Researchers searching for law on suspension of execution, admissibility/interest to act when the contested administrative act is withdrawn (including retroactive withdrawal), or judicial review standards for interim relief should retrieve this teaching.

rejected_topics.rejection_reason: Although the ruling turns on a procedural incident (recevabilité), A18.5 would be redundant given the selected A11.* topics which more directly capture the administrative-act, procedural-admissibility, and judicial-review dimensions of the teaching.

rejected_issue_types.rejection_reason: Factual assessment (whether prejudice existed) is background to the admissibility finding but the teaching does not provide actionable guidance on how to determine factual compliance; thus not materially engaged.

While the topic concerns an interlocutory remedy (suspension), the teaching focuses on admissibility rather than on the nature or content of remedies, so remedy-focused issue types are not materially engaged.
The decision is a substantive admissibility ruling by the reviewing court but does not discuss appeal/review procedures or standards for appellate review, so B24 is not materially engaged.

stage1_concepts: intérêt à agir / qualité pour agir (être ou risquer d'être lésé)
effet rétroactif du retrait (annulation rétroactive / disparition du préjudice)
moyen procédural d'irrecevabilité pour cause d'absence de préjudice
contrôle juridictionnel des actes administratifs (recours en suspension)

bodies_of_law_engaged: Administrative acts and their withdrawal/annulment (effects of retroactive withdrawal)
Administrative procedure governing interim relief (suspension requests under articles 14–15)
Judicial review of administrative action (admissibility of suspension, interest to act)
stage2_analysis.retrieval_consideration: Researchers searching for law on suspension of execution, admissibility/interest to act when the contested administrative act is withdrawn (including retroactive withdrawal), or judicial review standards for interim relief should retrieve this teaching.
granularity_decisions: Selected leaf nodes A11.2, A11.3, A11.4 because the teaching specifically addresses an administrative decision, the procedural admissibility rules for suspension requests, and judicial-review assessment of interim relief when the impugned act no longer produces effects.
Did not include the more specialized procedural-incidents node (A18.5) to avoid redundancy; A11.* nodes already capture the substantive and procedural aspects.

stage3_materiality.engagement_evidence: The teaching determines that one of the admissibility conditions in article 14 ('avoir été ou risquer d'être lésé') is not met when the attacked act is retroactively withdrawn, i.e., it applies the scope of the admissibility gate to the factual situation.
The decision addresses the applicant's standing/interest to seek suspension by analysing whether the applicant 'has been or risks being harmed' following retroactive withdrawal of the contested act.

The teaching resolves a procedural question of admissibility (recevabilité) for a suspension request and orders that the request be declared inadmissible because a formal condition is missing; this is in-forum procedural disposition.

production_rules_applied: No deterministic production rules triggered by the provided topic set (A11.2, A11.3, A11.4).

topic_set_details.materiality_evidence: The teaching describes a procedural rule applied by the Conseil d'État at the stage of the administrative procedure (maintaining confidentiality of annexed pieces when an uncontested request is made).

topic_set_details.topic_name: Administrative transparency and access to documents (FOI, disclosure disputes)
topic_set_details.materiality_evidence: The holding concerns confidentiality and access to documents filed in administrative proceedings (requests to restrict disclosure of annexes), directly engaging transparency/access-to-documents issues.

retrieval_info.description: Use set intersection for retrieval: match sources where topic_set ∩ query_topics ≠ ∅ AND issue_type_set ∩ query_issue_types ≠ ∅
retrieval_info.retrieval_queries: User queries about confidentiality requests for annexed documents in administrative proceedings, uncontested requests to keep filings confidential, and rules/practice of the Conseil d'État regarding access to administrative records.

rejected_topics.rejection_reason: Although the teaching involves an interlocutory procedural measure, A11.3 already captures the relevant procedural framework; A18.5 would be redundant and is less directly used by researchers searching for confidentiality/access issues before the Conseil d'État.

The decision is about procedural confidentiality in administrative proceedings rather than substantive trade-secret law or NDAs; while confidentiality is involved, the teaching does not materially analyze trade-secret doctrine.

rejected_issue_types.rejection_reason: Parties and standing are only backgrounded (behavioural facts about contestation) and not analyzed as an independent issue about capacity or authority.
Review/appeal is tangential; the teaching does not address whether such interlocutory confidentiality decisions are subject to appeal or the standards of review.

stage1_concepts: interim procedural measures to protect documents
administrative procedural practice before Conseil d'État
handling of annexed evidence and evidentiary secrecy

bodies_of_law_engaged: Administrative procedure (procedural rules before Conseil d'État)
Administrative transparency / access to administrative documents (confidentiality/exclusion from disclosure)
stage2_analysis.retrieval_consideration: User queries about confidentiality requests for annexed documents in administrative proceedings, uncontested requests to keep filings confidential, and rules/practice of the Conseil d'État regarding access to administrative records.
granularity_decisions: Select A11.3 (Administrative procedure) rather than a higher-level administrative law node because the teaching addresses a procedural-stage decision by the Conseil d'État.

Select A11.7 (Administrative transparency and access to documents) because the decision concerns confidentiality/access to documents filed in administrative proceedings and is more specific than a generic 'transparency' node.
Do not include A18.5 (Procedural incidents) because A11.3 already captures the procedural nature and is a clearer retrieval anchor for administrative-procedure queries.

stage3_materiality.engagement_evidence: The teaching prescribes how the court should decide at a specific procedural stage (maintain confidentiality of documents when a confidentiality request is made and remains uncontested). This is actionable guidance about in-forum mechanics at that stage.

The teaching concerns handling of evidentiary materials (confidentiality of pieces/files) and the court's decision whether to keep them confidential, which affects admissibility/access and evidentiary management.

The teaching sets the condition under which confidentiality is to be maintained (when the request is made and remains uncontested at the time of examination), defining the scope of the rule's application.

production_rules_applied: No A18.x topics present; no mandatory cross-inclusions required by deterministic rules.
